elements.content: Hydrothermal synthesis of Gd2O3 and iminodiacetic acid (H2IDA) yields a three-dimensional (3D) complex {[Gd2(IDA)3]·2H2O} n (1) including Gd16 macrocycles. Magnetic investigation indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interaction between GdIII ions and a large magnetocaloric effect with −ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg–1 K–1.
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal synthesis of Gd2O3 and iminodiacetic acid (H2IDA) yields a three-dimensional (3D) complex {[Gd2(IDA)3]⋅2H2O} n  (1) including Gd16 macrocycles. Magnetic investigation indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interaction between GdIII ions and a large magnetocaloric effect with -ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg-1 K-1.

elements.content: Hydrothermal synthesis of Gd2O3 and iminodiacetic acid yields a 3D complex composed of Gd16 macrocycles. Magnetic investigation indicates weak antiferromagnetic interaction between GdIII ions and a large magnetocaloric effect with −ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg−1 K−1.
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal synthesis of Gd2O3 and iminodiacetic acid yields a 3D complex composed of Gd16 macrocycles. Magnetic investigation indicates weak antiferromagnetic interaction between GdIII ions and a large magnetocaloric effect with -ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg-1 K-1.

elements.content: Design and synthesis of novel functional materials is one of the most important topics of modern science and technology and among them, the molecule-based magnetic coolers with an enhanced magnetocaloric effect (MCE) have attracted much attention. Due to the environmental safety and energy efficiency, magnetocaloric materials have been proposed to replace the expensive and increasingly rare He-3 in ultralow temperature refrigeration. The magnetic entropy change (ΔS m) is a key parameter to measure the magnitude of MCE, and consequently a large ΔS m in the requested temperature range is necessary for a material to be a good refrigerant. Previous studies have found that the MCE is greatly enhanced in molecules containing negligible magnetic anisotropy (D) ions with large total spin (S) and low-lying excited spin states. Hence, GdIII-based complexes were regarded as promising candidate materials for magnetic refrigerators, because of the large S, D = 0 of GdIII ion. Additionally, because of the very efficient shielding of the 4f orbitals of the GdIII, Gd–Gd magnetic exchange interactions are very weak, which is also profitably to enhance MCE. At present, many zero-dimensional (0D)/one-dimensional (1D)/two-dimensional (2D) 3d, 3d–4f, and 4f complexes have been well-exploited for MCE, nevertheless, the MCE explorations of three-dimensional (3D) GdIII complexes have rarely been reported.
elements.clean_text: Design and synthesis of novel functional materials is one of the most important topics of modern science and technology and among them, the molecule-based magnetic coolers with an enhanced magnetocaloric effect (MCE) have attracted much attention. Due to the environmental safety and energy efficiency, magnetocaloric materials have been proposed to replace the expensive and increasingly rare He-3 in ultralow temperature refrigeration. The magnetic entropy change (ΔS m) is a key parameter to measure the magnitude of MCE, and consequently a large ΔS m in the requested temperature range is necessary for a material to be a good refrigerant. Previous studies have found that the MCE is greatly enhanced in molecules containing negligible magnetic anisotropy (D) ions with large total spin (S) and low-lying excited spin states. Hence, GdIII-based complexes were regarded as promising candidate materials for magnetic refrigerators, because of the large S, D = 0 of GdIII ion. Additionally, because of the very efficient shielding of the 4f orbitals of the GdIII, Gd-Gd magnetic exchange interactions are very weak, which is also profitably to enhance MCE. At present, many zero-dimensional (0D)/one-dimensional (1D)/two-dimensional (2D) 3d, 3d-4f, and 4f complexes have been well-exploited for MCE, nevertheless, the MCE explorations of three-dimensional (3D) GdIII complexes have rarely been reported.

elements.content: Another factor favoring a large MCE is the presence of a relatively large metal/nonmetal mass ratio, in other words, reducing the amount of passive and nonmagnetic elements. Iminodiacetic acid (H2IDA) is a perfect candidate to form a GdIII-containing structure not only because it is a multidentate ligand including different electron donating groups (the imino and carboxyl) which could bind multiple GdIII ions to reduce the M W/N Gd ratio but also because it could be deprotonated to generate HIDA– and IDA2– ions by employing an alkaline substance in aqueous solution. A high-nuclearity cluster [Gd54Ni54] containing 108 metal ions and some other 4f/3d–4f complexes with the H2IDA ligand have been reported. However, their magnetocaloric properties have not been studied. Therefore, the relatively small H2IDA could be used for constructing GdIII complexes as potential molecule-based magnetic coolers. Herein, the magnetic properties of the GdIII complex {[Gd2(IDA)3]·2H2O} n (1) have been investigated in detail. It is worth mentioning that Gd2O3 does duty for both a slow-release metal ion source and a pH regulator in the reaction. If Gd2O3 was replaced by GdCl3·6H2O or Gd(NO3)3·6H2O as a lanthanide ion source, complex 1 was not found.
elements.clean_text: Another factor favoring a large MCE is the presence of a relatively large metal/nonmetal mass ratio, in other words, reducing the amount of passive and nonmagnetic elements. Iminodiacetic acid (H2IDA) is a perfect candidate to form a GdIII-containing structure not only because it is a multidentate ligand including different electron donating groups (the imino and carboxyl) which could bind multiple GdIII ions to reduce the M W/N Gd ratio but also because it could be deprotonated to generate HIDA- and IDA2- ions by employing an alkaline substance in aqueous solution. A high-nuclearity cluster [Gd54Ni54] containing 108 metal ions and some other 4f/3d-4f complexes with the H2IDA ligand have been reported. However, their magnetocaloric properties have not been studied. Therefore, the relatively small H2IDA could be used for constructing GdIII complexes as potential molecule-based magnetic coolers. Herein, the magnetic properties of the GdIII complex {[Gd2(IDA)3]⋅2H2O} n  (1) have been investigated in detail. It is worth mentioning that Gd2O3 does duty for both a slow-release metal ion source and a pH regulator in the reaction. If Gd2O3 was replaced by GdCl3⋅6H2O or Gd(NO3)3⋅6H2O as a lanthanide ion source, complex 1 was not found.

elements.content: Four isomorphous complexes have been reported very recently. Therefore, the structure of complex 1 is discussed briefly here. Complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4(1)/a space group, and the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two GdIII ions, three IDA2– anions, and two lattice H2O (Figure a). Each GdIII ion is nine coordinated, and its coordination polyhedron can be described as a distorted monocapped square antiprism. Gd1 is coordinated by seven O atoms of five different IDA2– anions and two N atoms of two IDA2– anions, while the Gd2 ion is coordinated by eight O atoms of six different IDA2– anions and one N atom of the IDA2– anion (Figure S1 of the ). The range of Gd–O bond lengths is 2.318(11)–2.612(11) Å, and O–Gd–O angles fall into the range from 143.8(4)° to 62.5(3)° (Table S2 of the ). The IDA2– anion adopts three kinds of coordination modes. One is that each anion employs one carboxylate with the μ3-η1:η2 bridging mode to connect one Gd1 and two Gd2 ions, and one O atom of the other carboxylate to link the same Gd1 ion (Figure S2a of the ). The second mode is one carboxylate connects one Gd2 and two Gd1 ions in the μ3-η1:η2 bridging mode, and the other carboxylate connects two Gd2 ions with the μ2-η1:η2 mode (Figure S2b of the ). As to the last mode, one carboxylate connects one Gd1 and two Gd2 ions in μ3-η1:η2 bridging mode and the other carboxylate links two Gd1 ions with μ2-η2 mode (Figure S2c of the SI). Interestingly, all the Gd16 macrocycles arrange neatly along the c axis with adjacent Gd16 macrocycles sharing four GdIII ions to form the 3D framework (Figure , panels b and c), which displays the beauty of the structure. Viewed along the a axis, the coordination framework can be seen as many parallel chains connected by two GdIII ions (Figure S3 of the ).
elements.clean_text: Four isomorphous complexes have been reported very recently. Therefore, the structure of complex 1 is discussed briefly here. Complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4(1)/a space group, and the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two GdIII ions, three IDA2- anions, and two lattice H2O (Figure a). Each GdIII ion is nine coordinated, and its coordination polyhedron can be described as a distorted monocapped square antiprism. Gd1 is coordinated by seven O atoms of five different IDA2- anions and two N atoms of two IDA2- anions, while the Gd2 ion is coordinated by eight O atoms of six different IDA2- anions and one N atom of the IDA2- anion (Figure S1 of the ). The range of Gd-O bond lengths is 2.318(11)-2.612(11) Å, and O-Gd-O angles fall into the range from 143.8(4)° to 62.5(3)° (Table S2 of the ). The IDA2- anion adopts three kinds of coordination modes. One is that each anion employs one carboxylate with the μ3-η1:η2 bridging mode to connect one Gd1 and two Gd2 ions, and one O atom of the other carboxylate to link the same Gd1 ion (Figure S2a of the ). The second mode is one carboxylate connects one Gd2 and two Gd1 ions in the μ3-η1:η2 bridging mode, and the other carboxylate connects two Gd2 ions with the μ2-η1:η2 mode (Figure S2b of the ). As to the last mode, one carboxylate connects one Gd1 and two Gd2 ions in μ3-η1:η2 bridging mode and the other carboxylate links two Gd1 ions with μ2-η2 mode (Figure S2c of the  SI). Interestingly, all the Gd16 macrocycles arrange neatly along the c axis with adjacent Gd16 macrocycles sharing four GdIII ions to form the 3D framework (Figure , panels b and c), which displays the beauty of the structure. Viewed along the a axis, the coordination framework can be seen as many parallel chains connected by two GdIII ions (Figure S3 of the ).

elements.content: As shown in Figure S4 (), the measured X-ray powder diffraction pattern closely match the simulated pattern generated from the result of single-crystal diffraction data, indicative of pure product. The thermogravimetric analysis result of 1 reveals that it is stable around 90 °C without any loss of lattice water molecules, which can be thoroughly removed under about 200 °C (Figure S5 of the ). In addition, the framework is stable at about 325 °C. The magnetic properties of 1 were investigated by solid-state magnetic susceptibility measurements in the 2–300 K range at a field of 1 kOe and the isothermal field-dependent magnetizations M(H) at 2 K at fields up to 70 kOe. (All the measurements were carried out on the sample of crushed crystals.) For 1, the χM T value is 15.55 emu mol–1 K at room temperature, which agrees with the expected spin-only value (15.76 emu mol–1 K) for two uncoupled GdIII ions. As the temperature decreases, the value of χM T slowly decreases down to a minimum value of 11.70 emu mol–1 K at 2 K (Figure ). As the GdIII ions present no spin–orbit coupling at the first order, the decrease of the χM T at low temperature points presumably to results from the presence of a very weak antiferromagnetic (AF) interaction between the GdIII ions. The Curie–Weiss fitting [χM = C/(T – θ)] of the magnetic data over 2–300 K gives C = 15.54 emu mol–1 K and θ = −0.90 K. The very small negative θ value also indicates the weak AF coupling. In addition, the magnetizations slowly increase and tend to a value of 13.79 Nβ at 70 kOe, and the experimental magnetization plot of 1 is just below the red line that presents the Brillouin function for two magnetically uncoupled GdIII ions with S = 7/2 and g = 2.0, which further confirms the weak AF behavior for 1 as similar literature (see Figure ). Given that 1 is a 3D framework with syn–syn–anti–μ3-η1:η2 and μ2-η2 carboxylate bridging ligands, there are three J values between GdIII ions. Therefore, it is difficult to fit the magnetic data of such a complicated S = 7/2 system. However, from the shape of the χM T curve and the starting and final values of χM T, a reasonable deduction is that J values should be very small, and negligible AF coupling exists between the GdIII ions, which results from the syn–anti carboxylate bridging ligands.

elements.content: (a) M vs H plots of 1 at T = 2–10 K and H = 5–70 kG. (b) Experimental −ΔS m obtained from magnetization data of 1 at different fields and temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) M vs H plots of 1 at T = 2-10 K and H = 5-70 kG. (b) Experimental -ΔS m obtained from magnetization data of 1 at different fields and temperatures.

elements.content: To characterize the low-temperature behavior of 1, the temperature dependencies of field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization were performed under a field of 50 Oe upon warming from 2 to 15 K (Figure S9 of the ). The FC curve agrees well with the ZFC curve, and the magnetizations increase continuously with decreasing temperature; no maximum is observed. These observations indicate that 1 does not exhibit a magnetic ordering above 2 K. Then we explored ΔS m in evaluating MCE on 1, considering the very weak GdIII···GdIII magnetic interaction and relatively low M W/N Gd ratio (315). The MCE can be calculated by employing the Maxwell equation as the following: ΔS m(T)ΔH = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T] H dH. According to the equation, we can obtain the −ΔS m of 1 from the experimental magnetization data (Figure a), and the curves of −ΔS m are depicted in Figure b. The −ΔS m per unit of mass reaches the maximum value of 40.6 J kg–1 K–1 [the calculated −ΔS m max is 46.49 J kg–1 K–1 by using 2R ln(2S + 1)] for a field change of ΔH = 70 kG at 2 K. Accordingly, the volumetric −ΔS m max for 1 is 100.69 mJ cm–3 K–1 (falling among the largest values known to date, see Table S1 of the ). Among the reported GdIII complexes which were developed as potential cryogenic molecule-based magnetic refrigerant materials, −ΔS m max above 35.0 J kg–1 K–1 is relatively rare (also summarized in Table S1 of the ). In addition, the −ΔS m per unit of mass reaches the value of 34.9 J kg–1 K–1 with ΔH = 40 kG, which is much larger than most reported GdIII complexes. However, the −ΔS m of 1 is lower than the calculated value as a significant splitting of the low-lying spin levels is expected in this system because of the AF exchange.
elements.clean_text: To characterize the low-temperature behavior of 1, the temperature dependencies of field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization were performed under a field of 50 Oe upon warming from 2 to 15 K (Figure S9 of the ). The FC curve agrees well with the ZFC curve, and the magnetizations increase continuously with decreasing temperature; no maximum is observed. These observations indicate that 1 does not exhibit a magnetic ordering above 2 K. Then we explored ΔS m in evaluating MCE on 1, considering the very weak GdIII⋅⋅⋅GdIII magnetic interaction and relatively low M W/N Gd ratio (315). The MCE can be calculated by employing the Maxwell equation as the following: ΔS m(T)ΔH  = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T] H  dH. According to the equation, we can obtain the -ΔS m of 1 from the experimental magnetization data (Figure a), and the curves of -ΔS m are depicted in Figure b. The -ΔS m per unit of mass reaches the maximum value of 40.6 J kg-1 K-1 [the calculated -ΔS m max is 46.49 J kg-1 K-1 by using 2R ln(2S + 1)] for a field change of ΔH = 70 kG at 2 K. Accordingly, the volumetric -ΔS m max for 1 is 100.69 mJ cm-3 K-1 (falling among the largest values known to date, see Table S1 of the ). Among the reported GdIII complexes which were developed as potential cryogenic molecule-based magnetic refrigerant materials, -ΔS m max above 35.0 J kg-1 K-1 is relatively rare (also summarized in Table S1 of the ). In addition, the -ΔS m per unit of mass reaches the value of 34.9 J kg-1 K-1 with ΔH = 40 kG, which is much larger than most reported GdIII complexes. However, the -ΔS m of 1 is lower than the calculated value as a significant splitting of the low-lying spin levels is expected in this system because of the AF exchange.

elements.content: In summary, by the hydrothermal reaction of Gd2O3 and H2IDA, a 3D GdIII complex containing Gd16 macrocycles along the c axis has been synthesized and structurally characterized. Magnetic studies of 1 reveal the existence of weak AF interactions and a large magnetocaloric effect (−ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg–1 K–1 for ΔH = 70 kG and T = 2 K). These results suggest that 1 could be regarded as a potential refrigerant for low-temperature applications. Further studies of carboxylate-bridged GdIII complexes with large MCE are under way in our group.
elements.clean_text: In summary, by the hydrothermal reaction of Gd2O3 and H2IDA, a 3D GdIII complex containing Gd16 macrocycles along the c axis has been synthesized and structurally characterized. Magnetic studies of 1 reveal the existence of weak AF interactions and a large magnetocaloric effect (-ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg-1 K-1 for ΔH = 70 kG and T = 2 K). These results suggest that 1 could be regarded as a potential refrigerant for low-temperature applications. Further studies of carboxylate-bridged GdIII complexes with large MCE are under way in our group.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Hydrothermal synthesis of Gd2O3 and iminodiacetic acid (H2IDA) yields a three-dimensional (3D) complex {[Gd2(IDA)3]·2H2O} n (1) including Gd16 macrocycles. Magnetic investigation indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interaction between GdIII ions and a large magnetocaloric effect with −ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg–1 K–1.

Hydrothermal synthesis of Gd2O3 and iminodiacetic acid yields a 3D complex composed of Gd16 macrocycles. Magnetic investigation indicates weak antiferromagnetic interaction between GdIII ions and a large magnetocaloric effect with −ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg−1 K−1.

As shown in Figure S4 (), the measured X-ray powder diffraction pattern closely match the simulated pattern generated from the result of single-crystal diffraction data, indicative of pure product. The thermogravimetric analysis result of 1 reveals that it is stable around 90 °C without any loss of lattice water molecules, which can be thoroughly removed under about 200 °C (Figure S5 of the ). In addition, the framework is stable at about 325 °C. The magnetic properties of 1 were investigated by solid-state magnetic susceptibility measurements in the 2–300 K range at a field of 1 kOe and the isothermal field-dependent magnetizations M(H) at 2 K at fields up to 70 kOe. (All the measurements were carried out on the sample of crushed crystals.) For 1, the χM T value is 15.55 emu mol–1 K at room temperature, which agrees with the expected spin-only value (15.76 emu mol–1 K) for two uncoupled GdIII ions. As the temperature decreases, the value of χM T slowly decreases down to a minimum value of 11.70 emu mol–1 K at 2 K (Figure ). As the GdIII ions present no spin–orbit coupling at the first order, the decrease of the χM T at low temperature points presumably to results from the presence of a very weak antiferromagnetic (AF) interaction between the GdIII ions. The Curie–Weiss fitting [χM = C/(T – θ)] of the magnetic data over 2–300 K gives C = 15.54 emu mol–1 K and θ = −0.90 K. The very small negative θ value also indicates the weak AF coupling. In addition, the magnetizations slowly increase and tend to a value of 13.79 Nβ at 70 kOe, and the experimental magnetization plot of 1 is just below the red line that presents the Brillouin function for two magnetically uncoupled GdIII ions with S = 7/2 and g = 2.0, which further confirms the weak AF behavior for 1 as similar literature (see Figure ). Given that 1 is a 3D framework with syn–syn–anti–μ3-η1:η2 and μ2-η2 carboxylate bridging ligands, there are three J values between GdIII ions. Therefore, it is difficult to fit the magnetic data of such a complicated S = 7/2 system. However, from the shape of the χM T curve and the starting and final values of χM T, a reasonable deduction is that J values should be very small, and negligible AF coupling exists between the GdIII ions, which results from the syn–anti carboxylate bridging ligands.

In summary, by the hydrothermal reaction of Gd2O3 and H2IDA, a 3D GdIII complex containing Gd16 macrocycles along the c axis has been synthesized and structurally characterized. Magnetic studies of 1 reveal the existence of weak AF interactions and a large magnetocaloric effect (−ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg–1 K–1 for ΔH = 70 kG and T = 2 K). These results suggest that 1 could be regarded as a potential refrigerant for low-temperature applications. Further studies of carboxylate-bridged GdIII complexes with large MCE are under way in our group.

† J.-M.J. and S.-J.L. contributed equally to this work.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

For example, see

For example, see:

Crystal data for 1: C12H19N3O14Gd2, M r = 743.80, tetragonal, I4(1)/a, a = 25.830(4) Å, c = 11.945(2) Å, V = 7970(2) Å3, Z = 16, D = 2.480 g cm–3, μ = 6.678 mm–1, F(000) = 5632, and GOF = 1.236. Of a total of 30913 reflections collected, 3512 are unique (R int = 0.1225). R 1/wR 2 = 0.0785/0.1793 [I > 2σ(I)].

However, from the shape of the χM T curve and the starting and final values of χM T, a reasonable deduction is that J values should be very small, and negligible AF coupling exists between the GdIII ions, which results from the syn-anti carboxylate bridging ligands. 

In summary, by the hydrothermal reaction of Gd2O3 and H2IDA, a 3D GdIII complex containing Gd16 macrocycles along the c axis has been synthesized and structurally characterized. Magnetic studies of 1 reveal the existence of weak AF interactions and a large magnetocaloric effect (-ΔS m max = 40.6 J kg-1 K-1 for ΔH = 70 kG and T = 2 K). These results suggest that 1 could be regarded as a potential refrigerant for low-temperature applications. Further studies of carboxylate-bridged GdIII complexes with large MCE are under way in our group.

 † J.-M.J. and S.-J.L. contributed equally to this work.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.
